citation.article-title: Gulosibacter molinativorax gen. nov., sp. nov., a molinate-degrading bacterium, and classification of 'Brevibacterium helvolum' DSM 20419 as Pseudoclavibacter helvolus gen. nov., sp. nov.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Pseudoclavibacter helvolus sp. nov.
Pseudoclavibacter helvolus (hel.vo′lus. L. adj. helvolus pale yellow, yellowish).
Irregular rod-shaped cells, 0·9–1·1 μm long and 0·4–0·5 μm wide.
Colonies grown on LA medium are yellow and about 2–3 mm in diameter after 48–72 h of growth.
Mesophilic; growth occurs at 10–35 °C, with optimum growth at 28–30 °C.
Maximal growth rate is observed in the presence of 1 % (w/v) NaCl; 8 % NaCl inhibits growth.

Aesculin, l-alanine, α-d-glucose, d-fructose, α-d-lactose, d-maltose, sucrose, d-raffinose, N-acetyl-d-glucosamine, glycerol, d-mannitol, pyruvic acid, methyl pyruvate, Tween 80, adenosine, 2′-deoxyadenosine, inosine, thymidine and uridine are utilized.
The DNA G+C content is 67 mol%.
The type strain is DSM 20419T (=ATCC 13715T), isolated from butter.
